comments.commentBody: As a bankruptcy attorney, I often represented clients who had let purportedly non-profit credit counseling agencies "consolidate" their payments by making a single monthly payment to the agency.  The agency would pay one or more credit card bills late so that, with the monthly late fees tacked on, my clients would find their total debt increasing.

This odious practice should be closely regulated by statute, where the debtor is given a written contract that guarantees a large return to the debtor with the person claiming the ability to substantially reduce with a written amount specifically stated and the person signing this contract with proof that he is who he claims to be be found criminally
liable with a large personal penalty & imprisonment.

Doesn't sound much different than every "mortgage modification" program.

There are "salesmen" and there are "sheeple".

Whatever financial scheme someone (Banks, Debt Consolidation companies, Obama) tries to sell you...just remember...you're the "mark".

It's all a scam.

Caveat Emptor.

Debt relief in America? Sure.

A vision of vultures come to mind. And the bones left afterward are those of the new middle class.

Alan

Barnum had us sized up some time ago.

Do-It-Yourself debt relief is quite simple.  You stave off payments to the credit card companies, skipping a month, sending in less than required, while SAVING CASH all the time, and not in a bank account.  When you have saved 40% of the most belligerent account balance, offer them 40% cash to buy out the debt.  In the meantime pay off all your very small debts such as overdue grocery bills, shoe repair, lawn maintenance, all the little people.  You must go on a CASH ONLY basis from the very beginning and it might mean giving up a lot of small pleasures.  Then start saving a large amount and tackle the next big card debt.  When you have finished, you should have no debts whatsoever and money that can now be put in the bank.  You would be surprised at how quickly this can be accomplished.  If you have a house mortgage that is 50% over the value of the house...WALK AWAY FROM IT...never never send them another dime, don't talk to them ignore them.  Eventually they will evict you, it may take up to a year.  They will offer all kinds of deals...IGNORE THEM!...you will only go deeper into debt eventually...they are not giving away anything but YOUR TIME and FUTURE.  Rent a cheap place until you are fully out of debt.  Stay in CASH mode until you can afford a modest home once again, a home that you should put 50% down on in CASH...takes time but then you are a free person.  You will be amazed when you discover you have 30% more income than when you were on a credit basis.  CASH FOLKS

This article is wise to point to the pitfalls of possibly shady debt solutions, of which we hear on the radio often. However, it is important to note that there are legitimate options available. I have been enrolled just over a year with a non profit debt management company, and this has absolutely saved my family. Like many who fell into trouble, when my husband lost his job, and I could not support a family of four on a museum salary, we began using credit cards for the most basic of needs; groceries, etc. When it became clear that this situation was getting out of control (living paycheck to paycheck, late payments were an unfortunate occurance, with the attending fees, and rising interest rates) I somehow heard about a nonprofit credit counseling agency. After close to three hours with them on the phone, reviewing everything from expenses, income, habits, etc. a plan was made. I was told that my creditors would have to approve. It was made clear to me that I would pay one sum a month, which would in turn be paid off to the various creditors. I still bore a responsibility to review statements, and of course, make sure my payments were made. And while my monthly payments altogether probably only dropped about 10% from what I was paying to the cards independently, the interest rate for all went from over 20% to about 6%. Thus, we will have all of our credit cards paid off within three years. I cannot explain the relief I feel upon reviewing the card statements each month and see that the total due is, indeed, diminishing, and that we will be debt free by 2013.
I imagine there are many like me, who wish to make good on outstanding debt. I recommend this avenue to do so.

My husband almost got snookered by one of these companies. I think it's so believable because the Big Banks appear to have gotten out of their debs without having to pay . . . so people think, why shouldn't the little guy, too? What the little guy doesn't understand is that the only free lunches out there are available to the people who can already afford lunch. And in the case of these "debt relief" companies, you ARE their lunch.

Thank goodness my husband came to his senses before he bankrupted the entire family. It took some pretty plain speech to get him to see who these guys really were and what game they were playing. You can bet I'm forwarding this article to him.
